tweet: False. Bitcoin cannot run solely on SPV clients because SPV clients can't mine (effectively), and there's still a bottleneck that the block creating entity has to process a load equal to the entire load of the network during that time. Sharding has none of these issues.
TBH, those people should do less of depending on others to help them and do more themselves in helping out Litecoin.
For people that care whether or not the creator of the coin owns the coin, Litecoin is probably not the right coin for them to own anyways.

Tradeoffs. One coin can't be best at everything. Bitcoin is most decentralized and secure, which means fees are higher. Litecoin targets a different mix of decentralization, security, speed, and fees.
The good news is that Apple can't 51% attack Bitcoin. There's a silver lining in all of this.
Bitcoin creates 10 times more mining rewards than Bitcoin Cash. So if Bitcoin dies, all these miners will be fighting for a much smaller pie. 90% of miners will become unprofitable.

That physics is important because of the resulting secure supply curve, validation, storage, transport, etc. properties, not inherently. Bitcoin & its predecessor design bit gold were designed to improve those properties, and in most ways Bitcoin is a huge improvement over gold.

The process of "unveiling itself", or reducing the uncertainty & increasing the shared knowledge about its nature & utility, that gold undoubtedly underwent in its early decades is just the process Lewis is referring to in Bitcoin. volatility = f(uncertainty, exchange).
